Revisiting Communication-Efficient Federated Learning with Balanced Global and Local Updates

Zhigang Yan, Dong Li Zhichao Zhang  and Jiguang He Zhigang Yan and Dong Li are with the Faculty of Information Technology, Macau University of Science and Technology, Macau, China. (e-mail: 2009853xim20001@student.must.edu.mo and dli@must.edu.mo). Zhichao Zhang is with the School of Mathematics and Statistics, Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology, Nanjing, China and also with the Faculty of Information Technology, Macau University of Science and Technology, Macau, China (e-mail: zzc910731@163.com). Jiguang He is with the Technology Innovation Institute, 9639 Masdar City, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates and also with Centre for Wireless Communications, FI-90014, University of Oulu, Finland (e-mail: jiguang.he@oulu.fi).
Abstract

In federated learning (FL), a number of devices train their local models and upload the corresponding parameters or gradients to the base station (BS) to update the global model while protecting their data privacy. However, due to the limited computation and communication resources, the number of local trainings (a.k.a. local update) and that of aggregations (a.k.a. global update) need to be carefully chosen. In this paper, we investigate and analyze the optimal trade-off between the number of local trainings and that of global aggregations to speed up the convergence and enhance the prediction accuracy over the existing works. Our goal is to minimize the global loss function under both the delay and the energy consumption constraints. In order to make the optimization problem tractable, we derive a new and tight upper bound on the loss function, which allows us to obtain closed-form expressions for the number of local trainings and that of global aggregations. Simulation results show that our proposed scheme can achieve a better performance in terms of the prediction accuracy, and converge much faster than the baseline schemes.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, resource allocation.

I Introduction

With the rapid development of wireless applications, a huge amount of data is generated every day. One traditional way to deal with these data is to simply send their data to a central controller for processing[1]. However, it incurs a new problem for heterogeneous data from different users concerning the privacy requirement or security/legal risks. In recent years, federated learning (FL) has been proposed and emerged as a promising solution to cope with the above challenges[2, 3]. In FL, a group of users train their local models with their own data, and send the training results, e.g., parameters or gradients, to the base station (BS) after several rounds of local training. The BS then aggregates their results to update the global model, and feeds the global parameters or gradients back to all the users to facilitate their local model update. Thus, the entire training process of FL constitutes several rounds of local training and global aggregation. However, the application of FL to wireless networks still faces several challenges, including the non-independent and identically distributed (non-i.i.d.) data from heterogeneous sources [4, 5, 6, 7, 8], data privacy during communication period [9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14], user scheduling for global aggregation [15, 16, 17, 18], and asynchronous local update [19, 20, 21].

Besides the above challenges, the practical implementation of FL suffers from limited communication resources. The existing works can be generally classified into two categories: 1) minimizing the cost/budget to save communication resources [22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29], 2) minimizing the loss function subject to communication resources restriction [30, 31, 32, 33, 34]. In the first category, the convergence time in FL with optimal bandwidth allocation and scheduling strategies was studied in [22]. Similarly, the delay in FL with optimal scheduling strategies was studied in [23]. The minimized delay in FL with optimal bandwidth allocation, scheduling strategies, and transmit power was studied in [24]. However, the optimal solutions were only evaluated numerically in [22, 23], and there are no closed-form expressions to facilitate the analyses. In addition, the energy cost was not involved in the above works. The total energy consumption was minimized with the latency constraint in [25, 26]. Furthermore, minimizing the sum of time and energy cost with the random scheduling strategy was respectively studied in [27], [28], and [29]. The optimal number of scheduled users, communication rounds, and training iterations were obtained in [27]. The optimal central processing unit (CPU) frequency, transmit power, and bandwidth allocation were obtained in [29]. However, the optimal scheduling strategies with limited resource blocks are only obtained in [27, 28].

In the second category, in order to minimize the loss function of FL, the optimal power allocation and scheduling strategy was studied in [30]. In addition, the optimal transmit power, resource block allocation, and user selection were investigated in [31]. However, both of them did not consider the trade-off between the number of local trainings and that of aggregations. An adaptive FL algorithm to minimize the loss function with optimal number of local trainings and aggregations was proposed in [32]. This algorithm was extended in  [33, 34] to obtain optimal number of scheduled users with resources limitation and total delay cost.

However, in most of existing works regarding the balanced global and local updates [32, 33, 34], there is a need to solve an optimization sub-problem according to the method proposed in [32] for each global aggregation, which will slow down the convergence. Besides, it is difficult, if not impossible, to obtain an accurate solution for the sub-problem, resulting in the deteriorated prediction accuracy. These observations motivate our work, and we attempt to break these bottlenecks to avoid solving the sub-problem by obtaining the closed-form expression for the optimal trade-off. Specifically, in this paper, we investigate and analyze the optimal trade-off between the local training and the global aggregation in the FL framework with communication resources restriction. The objective is to minimize the loss function of the global model while satisfying both the delay and energy consumption constraints. Our main contributions are summarized as follows:

  • •

    In order to make the optimization problem tractable, we derive a new upper bound of the loss function in a closed-from expression, which can be easily computed and extended to different types of training models and datasets. By doing so, we can avoid computing the optimization sub-problem as in most of existing works, and can thus speed up the convergence and boost the prediction accuracy accordingly. Besides, we also show that the derived upper bound is tight under certain conditions.

  • •

    Based on the derived upper bound, we are able to reformulate the original problem, which allows us to obtain closed-from expressions for the number of local trainings and the number of global aggregations. The advantages are that the resultant computational complexity is low, and the impact of the major system parameters can be easily revealed.

  • •

    Simulation results show that the proposed scheme can not only significantly improve the convergence speed, but also achieve a better performance than the existing ones in terms of the prediction accuracy.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the system model and formulate the optimization problem. The analysis on the convergence bound is presented in Section III. The convergence analysis is finished in Section IV. We solve the problem by obtaining closed-from expressions for optimized solutions in Section V. The simulation results are shown in Section VI and the concluding remarks are given in Section VII.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

II-A Global and local updates for Federated Learning

The system under consideration consists of a BS for global aggregation, and N𝑁N users for local training. For FL, the loss function is commonly utilized for performance evaluation, and the goal is to find the optimal parameter that minimizes the loss function, i.e.,

𝐰∗=argmin𝐰∈ℝnF​(𝐰),superscript𝐰subscriptargmin𝐰superscriptℝ𝑛𝐹𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}=\operatorname*{argmin}\limits_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}F(\mathbf{w}), (1)

where the notations are defined in Table I,111Note that a bold lowercase letter denotes a vector, ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| denotes the Euclidean norm of a vector, 𝔼​(⋅)𝔼⋅\mathbb{E}(\cdot) denotes a mathematical expectation of variable and ℙ​(⋅)ℙ⋅\mathbb{P}(\cdot) denotes the probability of event. and some examples of loss functions are provided in Table II.222In the classification model, y𝑦y and p𝑝p denote the ground-truth label of a sample and the probability that this model predicts it correctly. While, in the regression model, 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} is the value vector of features, and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is the ground-truth label. f​(𝐱i)𝑓subscript𝐱𝑖f(\mathbf{x}_{i}) is the predicted value of this model.

In order to obtain 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} in (1), it is necessary to conduct local training at each user by using its own data. That is, every user uses its own data to train a local model. Specifically, the i𝑖ith user updates the parameters of its local model by using the following gradient descent method:

𝐰i​(t)=𝐰i​(t−1)−η​∇Fi​(𝐰i​(t−1)).subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1\mathbf{w}_{{i}}({t})=\mathbf{w}_{{i}}({t}-\mathrm{1})-\eta\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w}_{{i}}({t}-\mathrm{1})). (2)

After several rounds of local training, the local parameters from all the users will be delivered to the BS, which aggregates them to update the global model. In particular, between two adjacent global aggregations, there will be several rounds of local training. In the paper, we adopt the FedAvg algorithm for the global aggregation [3], which is given by

𝐰​(t)=∑i=1NDi​𝐰i​(t)D.𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡𝐷\mathbf{w}({t})=\frac{\sum\limits_{i=\mathrm{1}}^{N}{{D_{i}}\mathbf{w}_{{i}}({t})}}{{D}}. (3)

After updating the global model, the BS broadcasts the global parameters to every user. Furthermore, the parameter of the local model 𝐰~i​(t)subscript~𝐰𝑖𝑡\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}(t) can be summarized as follow:

𝐰~i​(t)={∑i=1NDi​𝐰i​(t)D,t=k​τ,𝐰i​(t−1)−η​∇Fi​(𝐰i​(t−1)),otherwise.subscript~𝐰𝑖𝑡casessuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡𝐷𝑡𝑘𝜏subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1otherwise{\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}(t)}=\begin{cases}\frac{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}{{D_{i}}\mathbf{w}_{{i}}({t})}}{{D}},&t=k\tau,\\ {\mathbf{w}_{{i}}({t}-\mathrm{1})-\eta\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w}_{{i}}({t}-\mathrm{1})),}&{\text{otherwise}}.\end{cases} (4)

The parameter of the local model is updated by using (3) when t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau. Otherwise, its update follows (2).

The global loss function is defined as333The index (t)𝑡(t) is omitted thereafter for simplicity of illustration.

F​(𝐰)=∑i=1NDi​Fi​(𝐰)D.𝐹𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰𝐷{F}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{\sum\limits_{{i}=\mathrm{1}}^{{N}}{D_{i}F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})}{{D}}. (5)

It is indicated that F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰{F}(\mathbf{w}) cannot be calculated directly by following Table II due to the lack of users’ data at the BS. Instead, we refer to (5) for computing F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰{F}(\mathbf{w}) after global aggregation.

II-B System Delay Model

1) Local Training Delay: According to [33] and [35], the local training delay of the i𝑖ith user (e.g., ti,t​rsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑡𝑟t_{i,tr}) follows the shifted exponential distribution, it means that

ℙ​(ti,t​r−ai​τ​di≤t)={1−e−μiτ​di​t,t≥0,0,otherwise,ℙsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑡𝑟subscript𝑎𝑖𝜏subscript𝑑𝑖𝑡cases1superscript𝑒subscript𝜇𝑖𝜏subscript𝑑𝑖𝑡𝑡00otherwise{\mathbb{P}(t_{i,tr}-a_{i}\tau d_{i}\leq t)}=\begin{cases}1-e^{-\frac{\mu_{i}}{\tau d_{i}}t},&t\geq 0,\\ {0,}&{\text{otherwise}},\end{cases} (6)

where disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} is the batch size of local training of the i𝑖ith user. If we apply the Stochastic Gradient Descent to update all local models, we simply set di=1subscript𝑑𝑖1d_{i}=1 to any i𝑖i. Besides, μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i} and aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} denote the fluctuation and the maximum of the computation capabilities [33]. If disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} is the same, the aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} will be the same [35]. To this end, we consider μi=μsubscript𝜇𝑖𝜇\mu_{i}=\mu to any i𝑖i.

In order to achieve synchronous update of all local models, all users are allowed to send parameters to the BS when all of them finish the local training. Therefore, the training delay of all users (e.g., tt​rsubscript𝑡𝑡𝑟t_{tr}) depends on the maximal ti,t​rsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑡𝑟t_{i,tr}, namely, tt​r≜max⁡{ti,t​r}≜subscript𝑡𝑡𝑟subscript𝑡𝑖𝑡𝑟t_{tr}\triangleq\max\{t_{i,tr}\}.

Theorem 1: The upper bound of mathematical expectation of tt​rsubscript𝑡𝑡𝑟t_{tr} is given by

𝔼​(max⁡{ti,t​r})≤N​τμ⋅I0+a​τ,𝔼subscript𝑡𝑖𝑡𝑟⋅𝑁𝜏𝜇subscript𝐼0𝑎𝜏\mathbb{E}(\max\{t_{i,tr}\})\leq\frac{N\tau}{\mu}\cdot I_{0}+a\tau, (7)

where a=max⁡{ai}𝑎subscript𝑎𝑖a=\max\{a_{i}\}, and I0=∑i=1NCN−1i−1​(−1)i−1i2subscript𝐼0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁1𝑖1superscript1𝑖1superscript𝑖2I_{0}=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{C_{N-1}^{i-1}(-1)^{i-1}}{i^{2}}.

Proof: See Appendix A.∎absent\hfill\qed

Theorem 1 shows that, a higher frequency of aggregation will lead to a lower average local training delay.

2) Communication Delay: After several rounds of local training, all users need to send their local parameters to the BS. Then the BS averages the parameters and broadcasts to all users. Therefore, the communication delay includes the upload and download delay. However, we ignore the download delay in this paper because the transmit power of BS is large enough to make the download delay small.

The upload delay depends on the bit number of parameters which will be sent (e.g., Z​(𝐰)𝑍𝐰Z(\mathbf{w})) and the achievable transmission rate of the system. We apply an FDMA system in the communication part of FL, therefore, the communication delay is

ti,c​m=Z​(𝐰)B​log2⁡(1+Pc​m​hiN0),subscript𝑡𝑖𝑐𝑚𝑍𝐰𝐵subscript21subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscriptℎ𝑖subscript𝑁0t_{i,cm}=\frac{Z(\mathbf{w})}{B\log_{2}(1+\frac{P_{cm}h_{i}}{N_{0}})}, (8)

where B𝐵B and hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i} is the bandwidth and the channel gain of the i𝑖ith user respectively. N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the noise power. In our communication delay model, ti,c​msubscript𝑡𝑖𝑐𝑚t_{i,cm} will be treated as a constant. This treatment is common in works similar to this paper, such as [33] and [34]. Besides, similar to the analysis of the local training delay, we consider the communication delay of all users denoted as tc​m=max⁡{ti,c​m}subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑖𝑐𝑚t_{cm}=\max\{t_{i,cm}\}.

II-C System Energy Consumption Model

1) Energy consumption of local training: The energy consumption of local training depends on the computation capacity of the user. According to [25], the energy consumption of one round of local training in the i𝑖ith user can be written as

Ei,t​r=κ​C​Di​ai2,subscript𝐸𝑖𝑡𝑟𝜅𝐶subscript𝐷𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑎2𝑖E_{i,tr}=\kappa CD_{i}a^{2}_{i}, (9)

where κ𝜅\kappa is the effective switched capacitance that depends on the chip architecture. C𝐶C is is the number of CPU cycles, and Et​r=max⁡{Ei,t​r}=κ​C​Dm​a​x​a2subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟subscript𝐸𝑖𝑡𝑟𝜅𝐶subscript𝐷𝑚𝑎𝑥superscript𝑎2E_{tr}=\max\{E_{i,tr}\}=\kappa CD_{max}a^{2}.

2) Energy consumption of communication: We have obtain the communication delay in (8), therefore, the Energy consumption of communication is Ec​m=Pc​m​tc​msubscript𝐸𝑐𝑚subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚E_{cm}=P_{cm}t_{cm}, and Pc​msubscript𝑃𝑐𝑚P_{cm} will be also treated as a constant [25].

II-D Problem Formulation

In this paper, our goal is to find the optimal trade-off between the number of local trainings and that of global aggregations by minimizing the global loss function. The optimization problem is formulated as

minT,KF​(𝐰)subscript𝑇𝐾𝐹𝐰\displaystyle\min_{T,K}\quad{F}(\mathbf{w}) (10)
s.t.𝔼​(tt​r)⋅T+tc​m​K≤tt​o​t,s.t.⋅𝔼subscript𝑡𝑡𝑟𝑇subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚𝐾subscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡\displaystyle\;\textrm{s.t.}\quad\mathbb{E}(t_{tr})\cdot T+t_{cm}K\leq t_{tot}, (10a)
Et​r⋅T+Ec​m​K≤Et​o​t,⋅subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟𝑇subscript𝐸𝑐𝑚𝐾subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡\displaystyle\quad\quad E_{tr}\cdot T+E_{cm}K\leq E_{tot}, (10b)
t≤T,𝑡𝑇\displaystyle\quad\quad t\leq T, (10c)
T=K​τ,𝑇𝐾𝜏\displaystyle\quad\quad T=K\tau, (10d)

where (10a) and (10b) denote the delay and energy consumption constraints, respectively. It is noted that in both (10a) and (10b), we focus on the communication resources for the local model and neglect those for the global model similar to existing works. This is due to the obvious contrast between BS and users in terms of the computation capacity and the energy availability. Besides, (10c) and (10d) require that the number of the global aggregations should be less than or equal to the total number of local trainings, and the total number of local trainings should be an integer-fold of the number of aggregations.

III Convergence Analysis of FL

The optimization problem (10) has optimal solution means the loss fuction of FL is convergent. Therefore, we are going to analyze convergence of the loss function and its convergence rate in this section.

The following assumptions are utilized to finish the convergence analysis.

Assumption 1

For each user and any pair of 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} and 𝐰′superscript𝐰′\mathbf{w}^{\prime}

  1. 1.

    Fi​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w}) is convex

  2. 2.

    Fi​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w}) is ρ𝜌\rho-Lipscitz: ‖Fi​(𝐰)−Fi​(𝐰′)‖≤ρ​‖𝐰−𝐰′‖normsubscript𝐹𝑖𝐰subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝐰′𝜌norm𝐰superscript𝐰′\|{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})-{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w}^{\prime})\|\leq\rho\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\|

  3. 3.

    Fi​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w}) is β𝛽\beta-Smooth: ‖∇Fi​(𝐰)−∇Fi​(𝐰′)‖≤β​‖𝐰−𝐰′‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝐰′𝛽norm𝐰superscript𝐰′\|\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w}^{\prime})\|\leq\beta\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\|

  4. 4.

    (Gradient divergence) For any i𝑖i and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} is an upper bound of ‖∇Fi​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰)‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰∇𝐹𝐰\|\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla{F}(\mathbf{w})\|, i.e.,

    ‖∇Fi​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰)‖≤δi.norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰∇𝐹𝐰subscript𝛿𝑖\|\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla{F}(\mathbf{w})\|\leq\delta_{{i}}. (11)

    We define δ=∑i=1NDi​δiD𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖𝐷\delta=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}D_{i}\delta_{i}}{D}.

  5. 5.

    (Federated learning gap) ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the lower bound of F​(𝐰​(T))−F​(𝐰∗)𝐹𝐰𝑇𝐹superscript𝐰{F}(\mathbf{w}({T}))-{F}(\mathbf{w}^{*}), i.e.,

    F​(𝐰​(T))−F​(𝐰∗)≥ϵ.𝐹𝐰𝑇𝐹superscript𝐰italic-ϵ{F}(\mathbf{w}({T}))-{F}(\mathbf{w}^{*})\geq\epsilon. (12)

A proportion of loss functions are shown in Table II satisfying 1)-3) in Assumption 1. These loss functions are often used in some classification models and regression models, such as support vector machine (SVM), convolutional neural network (CNN), and linear regression, which will be examined later in our simulations in Section V. Regarding 4) of Assumption 1, gradient divergence reflects the difference among data distributions of all the users. If the data distributions are similar to each other, the gradient divergence will be small, and vice versa. Furthermore, 5) of Assumption 1 reflects the difference between model trained by FL and that trained by centralized machine learning.

Assumption 2: The gradient of the global model is upper bounded by

∇F∗=argmax∇F​(𝐰)∈ℝn‖∇F​(𝐰)‖.∇superscript𝐹subscriptargmax∇𝐹𝐰superscriptℝnnorm∇𝐹𝐰\nabla\mathit{F}^{*}=\operatorname*{argmax}\limits_{\nabla\mathit{F}(\mathbf{w})\in\mathrm{\mathbb{R}^{n}}}\|\nabla{F}(\mathbf{w})\|. (13)

Assumption 2 is motivated by the fact that the loss function of the global model can only be calculated based on the information (e.g., data and parameters) about the local model. Meanwhile, the number of aggregations is limited, so the gradients of global loss function are restricted in a finite set.

According to Assumptions 1 and 2, we are able to propose the following lemmas.

Theorem 2: For any i𝑖i and t𝑡t, we have

Theorem 2 gives an upper bound of the difference between the parameters of the i𝑖ith user after the t𝑡tth local training and the parameters of global model after the T𝑇Tth local training. From Theorem 2, it is known that the smaller the upper bound, the better the local model. Recall that t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau when FL aggregates after the t𝑡tth local training. In particular, when t=0𝑡0t=0, k=0𝑘0k=0 and gi​(0)=0subscript𝑔𝑖00g_{i}(0)=0. In FL, a larger τ𝜏\tau will cause the local model overfitting. On the contrary, a smaller τ𝜏\tau makes the local model underfitting. In Theorem 1, k𝑘k should be larger than or equal to ⌈1ρ​η​(δi+∇F∗)⌉1𝜌𝜂subscript𝛿𝑖∇superscript𝐹\lceil\frac{1}{\rho\eta(\delta_{i}+\nabla F^{*})}\rceil, leading to a positive value of gi​(t)subscript𝑔𝑖𝑡g_{i}(t) in practice.

Theorem 3: The upper bound of F​(𝐰​(T))−F​(𝐰∗)𝐹𝐰𝑇𝐹superscript𝐰{F}(\mathbf{w}({T}))-{F}(\mathbf{w}^{*}) is given by

F​(𝐰​(T))−F​(𝐰∗)≤ϵ2ρ​gi​(1)+ρ​η​∇F∗​T.𝐹𝐰𝑇𝐹superscript𝐰superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜌subscript𝑔𝑖1𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹𝑇\mathit{F}(\mathbf{w}(\mathit{T}))-\mathit{F}(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{\rho{g_{i}}(\mathrm{1})+\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}T}}. (16)

Proof: See Appendix D.∎absent\hfill\qed

It is observed from Theorem 3 that a larger T𝑇T and a smaller τ𝜏\tau lead to a lower upper bound of F​(𝐰​(T))−F​(𝐰∗)𝐹𝐰𝑇𝐹superscript𝐰{F}(\mathbf{w}({T}))-{F}(\mathbf{w}^{*}). Besides, it can be also deduced from Theorem 2 that how the distribution of the data influence the convergence. Provided that ϵ≈δiitalic-ϵsubscript𝛿𝑖\epsilon\approx\delta_{i}, the denominator ρ​gi​(1)+ρ​η​∇F∗​t𝜌subscript𝑔𝑖1𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹𝑡\rho{g_{i}(\mathrm{1})}+\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}t} are much larger than the numerator ϵ2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon^{2}, so the numerator is more sensitive to value changes of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. For non-i.i.d. data, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} will be larger compared to the case of i.i.d. data. This in turn indicates that the non-i.i.d. data will lead to a larger upper bound, which will be verified in Section V.

Theorem 3 also reflects that, if we fix the frequency of aggregation (e.g., τ𝜏\tau), ϵ2ρ​gi​(1)+ρ​η​∇F∗​tsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜌subscript𝑔𝑖1𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹𝑡\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{\rho{g_{i}}(\mathrm{1})+\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}t}} decreases with increasing rounds of local training (e.g., t𝑡t). Thus, the loss function of FL can be shown to be convergent.

In order to get more insight into Theorem 3, we present two corollaries, which depicts the tightness and the number of local training after convergence, respectively.

Corollary 1: If the parameters satisfy the following conditions, the upper bound in (16) is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-tight.

1) 𝐰i​(1)=m​𝐰​(T),m∈ℝ+,∀iformulae-sequencesubscript𝐰𝑖1𝑚𝐰𝑇𝑚superscriptℝfor-all𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}(1)=m\mathbf{w}(T),m\in\mathbb{R}^{+},\forall i.

2) ∇Fi​(𝐰​(t))=p​∇F​(𝐰​(t)),p∈ℝ+,∀iformulae-sequence∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰𝑡𝑝∇𝐹𝐰𝑡𝑝superscriptℝfor-all𝑖\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}(t))=p\nabla F(\mathbf{w}(t)),p\in\mathbb{R}^{+},\forall i.

3) 𝐰~i​(t)=q​𝐰​(t),q∈ℝ+,∀iformulae-sequencesubscript~𝐰𝑖𝑡𝑞𝐰𝑡𝑞superscriptℝfor-all𝑖\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}(t)=q\mathbf{w}(t),q\in\mathbb{R}^{+},\forall i.

4) 𝐰​(t)−𝐰​(T)=−s​∇F​(𝐰​(t)),s∈ℝ+formulae-sequence𝐰𝑡𝐰𝑇𝑠∇𝐹𝐰𝑡𝑠superscriptℝ\mathbf{w}(t)-\mathbf{w}(T)=-s\nabla F(\mathbf{w}(t)),s\in\mathbb{R}^{+}.

Proof: In the proof of Theorem 3, if the equality condition of each step can be satisfied, the upper bound of Theorem 3 will be tight. That is to say, when conditions 1)-4) are satisfied, (36)-(47) are achievable. Thus, we can arrive at Corollary 1 after some manipulations. ∎absent\hfill\qed

In Corollary 1, 1) means that the first parameter vectors of all users are in parallel and with the same direction as the final global parameter vector. 2) means the gradient of every users are in parallel and with the same direction as the global gradient in each round of aggregate. 3) means if one round will aggregate, this parameter vector after aggregation is in parallel and with the same direction as this vector without any aggregation. 4) means the global parameter vector changes in the opposite direction to the gradient. It is not difficult to see that when the FL system has only one user, all conditions will be satisfied. Besides, if the loss function also satisfies that ϵ=0italic-ϵ0\epsilon=0 which is the infimum of F​(𝐰​(T))−F​(𝐰∗)𝐹𝐰𝑇𝐹superscript𝐰{F}(\mathbf{w}({T}))-{F}(\mathbf{w}^{*}) and ρ=F′​(ξ)𝜌superscript𝐹′𝜉\rho=F^{\prime}(\xi), where ξ𝜉\xi is the value which satisfies Lagrange’s Mean Value Theorem of F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰{F}(\mathbf{w}), the upper bound in (16) is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-tight.

From the Theorem 3, we obtain the convergence gap of FL. Thus, we can use the number of local trainings which the gap can arrive a small enough value (e.g., ε𝜀\varepsilon) to reflect the convergence rate. Therefore, we obtain the proposition of Theorem 3 as follow:

Corollary 2: The number of local trainings after ε𝜀\varepsilon convergence is at least 1ρ​η​∇F∗​(ϵ2ε−ρ​η​(δi+∇F∗)+τ)1𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜀𝜌𝜂subscript𝛿𝑖∇superscript𝐹𝜏\frac{1}{\rho\eta\nabla F^{*}}(\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{\varepsilon}-\rho\eta(\delta_{i}+\nabla F^{*})+\tau).

Proof: The proof simply follows from (16), and thus omitted for brevity.∎absent\hfill\qed

IV Optimal Trade-off between the Local Trainings and the Global Aggregations

In this section, we are going to solve the optimization problem in (10) with constraints (10a)-(10d), which is, however, hard to deal with due to the intractable objective function in (10). In [32], an adaptive method was proposed to transform (10) to facilitate the optimization process. However, it incurs a new optimization sub-problem in each iteration, which harms the convergence speed. In this paper, we propose a new method to circumvent this problem, in which (10) is derived in a closed-form expression.

Finally, the objective function in (10) can be replaced by the upper bound in (16), and the original optimization problem is reformulated as

minτ,Kϵ2ρ​gi​(1)+ρ​η​∇F∗​K​τ,subscript𝜏𝐾superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜌subscript𝑔𝑖1𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹𝐾𝜏\displaystyle\min_{\tau,K}\quad\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{\rho{g_{i}(\mathrm{1})}+\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}K\tau}}, (17)
s.t.(Nμ⋅I0+a)​K​τ2+tc​m​K≤tt​o​t,s.t.⋅𝑁𝜇subscript𝐼0𝑎𝐾superscript𝜏2subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚𝐾subscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡\displaystyle\;\textrm{s.t.}\quad(\frac{N}{\mu}\cdot I_{0}+a)K\tau^{2}+t_{cm}K\leq t_{tot}, (17a)
Et​r​K​τ+Ec​m​K≤Et​o​t.subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟𝐾𝜏subscript𝐸𝑐𝑚𝐾subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡\displaystyle\quad\quad E_{tr}K\tau+E_{cm}K\leq E_{tot}. (17b)

IV-A Proposed Solution

In (13), ϵ2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon^{2}, ρ​η​(δ+∇F∗)𝜌𝜂𝛿∇superscript𝐹\rho\eta(\delta+\nabla{F^{*}}), and ρ​η​∇F∗𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}} are constants, and ρ​η​(δ+∇F∗)+(ρ​η​∇F∗−1K)​T>0𝜌𝜂𝛿∇superscript𝐹𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹1𝐾𝑇0\rho\eta(\delta+\nabla{F^{*}})+(\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}}-\frac{1}{K})T>\textrm{0}. In this regard, the optimization problem in (17) can be further transformed into the following:

minτ,Kτ−ρ​η​∇F∗​K​τ,subscript𝜏𝐾𝜏𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹𝐾𝜏\displaystyle\min_{\tau,K}\quad\tau-\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}}K\tau, (18)
s.t.(17​a),(17​b).s.t.17a17b\displaystyle\;\textrm{s.t.}\quad(17\mathrm{a}),(17\mathrm{b}).

It can be checked that (18) is non-convex over K𝐾K and τ𝜏\tau, which renders the problem hard to solve. However, the following theorem reveals the optimal solutions to (18).

Theorem 4: The solution that satisfies the KKT conditions of (18) is given by (19) on the top of this page, where I1=Et​r2​tt​o​t2−4​Et​o​t​(I0​N​μ+a)​(tc​m​Et​o​t−Pc​m​tc​m​tt​o​t)subscript𝐼1subscriptsuperscript𝐸2𝑡𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝑡2𝑡𝑜𝑡4subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡I_{1}=E^{2}_{tr}t^{2}_{tot}-4E_{tot}(I_{0}N\mu+a)(t_{cm}E_{tot}-P_{cm}t_{cm}t_{tot}). Let Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i} and τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i} as the values of (19), i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2. The optimal solution of (18) is given by (21) on the top of this page.

Proof: See Appendix E.∎absent\hfill\qed

From the Theorem 4, it is seen that the optimal number of local trainings and global aggregations also depend on the data distribution at each user. The i.i.d. data is beneficial for training and thus the loss function is easy to convergence. Therefore, the i.i.d. data brings a higher ∇F∗∇superscript𝐹\nabla F^{*} and a lower training delay.

In Algorithm 1, lines 1 and 2 provide the initial values to the hyperparameters. τm​a​xsubscript𝜏𝑚𝑎𝑥\tau_{max} is the maximal τ𝜏\tau to prevent the model overfitting during the training. Line 4 computes the λ𝜆\lambda to determine the optimal value τ𝜏\tau and K𝐾K. Line 8 sets the range value of τ𝜏\tau as {1,2,…,20}12…20\{1,2,\dots,20\} to avoid overfitting. Lines 10 to 17 are the detailed steps of FL, which include the local training phase and the communication phase. The maximum of t𝑡t is T∗superscript𝑇T^{*}, which is obtained in Line 7. When t𝑡t is an integer-fold of τ𝜏\tau, the FL performs the aggregation. Finally, the algorithm outputs the 𝐰​(T∗)𝐰superscript𝑇\mathbf{w}(T^{*}).

V Simulation Results

V-A System Setup

1) Parameters: For our simulations, we consider an FL system with five users and one BS. For simplicity of illustration, we run simulations to compute the average time delay of local training and communication/aggregation. To be specific, we have tc​m=0.14subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚0.14t_{cm}=0.14s in the SVM model, and tc​m=0.143subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚0.143t_{cm}=0.143s in the CNN model. Because CNN has more parameters than SVM, it has a larger Z​(𝐰)𝑍𝐰Z(\mathbf{w}). Thus its tc​msubscript𝑡𝑐𝑚t_{cm} longer is realistic. The other parameters used in the simulations are listed in Table III.

To reflect the lower convergence speed in the case of non-i.i.d. data for model training, we set a lower value of ∇F∗∇superscript𝐹\nabla F^{*} in the simulation. In general, the CNN model has more parameters than the SVM model, so we set a larger value of ∇F∗∇superscript𝐹\nabla F^{*} in CNN. Finally, in the same model, training on a larger dataset makes the value of ∇F∗∇superscript𝐹\nabla F^{*} larger. We summarize ∇F∗∇superscript𝐹\nabla F^{*} in different cases in Table IV.

2) Datasets: In our simulations, for simplicity of comparison, we consider 444 different datasets, which represent different data sizes, sample complexities, and data distributions. All the datasets are used for training a classification model.

The first dataset is MNIST, which contains 70,0007000070,000 gray-scale images of handwritten digits (60,0006000060,000 for training and 10,0001000010,000 for testing). The second one is CIFAR-10, which contains 60,0006000060,000 color images (50,0005000050,000 for training and 10,0001000010,000 for testing) of 101010 different types of objects. Compared to MNIST, CIFAR-10 represents a lower data size but larger number of channels.

Besides, we consider 222 cases to make these two datasets have different data distributions in our simulations. In case 111, each data sample is randomly assigned to a user, so each user has i.i.d. data. In case 222, all the data samples in each user have the same label. However, the samples in the whole datasets have multiple different labels. Therefore, each user have non-i.i.d. data in case 222.

3) Models: We use 2 different models in our simulations for the classification tasks. The first one is SVM for binary classification, which is applied in MNIST dataset to predict whether the digit in the sample picture is even or odd. The second one is CNN, which is applied in MNIST dataset for binary classification (same as SVM) and CIFAR-10 dataset for multi-class classification.

4) Baseline: We take the adaptive FL algorithm [32] as the baseline for our work.

V-B Results and Observations

1) Impact of non-i.i.d. Datasets

In the first part of our simulations, both SVM and CNN are trained for every user. We compare the loss value and prediction accuracy with τ∈{1,⋯,100}𝜏1⋯100\tau\in\{1,\cdots,100\} in different cases. The results are shown in Fig. 1.

We see that in different cases with the i.i.d. dataset, as τ𝜏\tau increases, the loss value decreases and predict accuracy improves. In the CNN model, the optimal τ𝜏\tau is large and close to 100100100 while close to 202020 in the SVM model. However, we see the loss value of CNN is stable when τ𝜏\tau is more than 202020. Therefore, to avoid overfitting, we set τm​a​xsubscript𝜏𝑚𝑎𝑥\tau_{max} to be 202020. In the non-i.i.d. dataset, the curves for the loss value represent a “U” shape. The optimal τ𝜏\tau’s are close to 101010, which is consistent with the analysis in Theorem 222. It indicates that training model with the non-i.i.d. data need more aggregations (e.g. a lower τ𝜏\tau). With the parameters setup in our simulations, the theoretical optimal τ𝜏\tau’s in different cases are shown in Table V, which almost coincide with the numerical results in Fig. 1.

2) Impact of tt​o​tsubscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡t_{tot} and Et​o​tsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡E_{tot}

In the second part of our simulations, we show the performance of different models, datasets, and data distributions with varying tt​o​tsubscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡t_{tot} and Et​o​tsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡E_{tot}. The results are shown in Fig. 2.

Since all cases have already converged, we can evaluate the performance of our proposed update algorithm in these cases. Compared with SVM, the performance of CNN is significantly influenced by the data distribution. Besides, with the i.i.d. dataset, the CNN performs better than the SVM. On the contrary, the SVM outperforms the CNN with the non-i.i.d. dataset. Because CNN is a more complex model (i.e. more parameters) than SVM, it can perform better than SVM ideally. However, CNN is also easy to overfit with non-i.i.d. data, so that CNN performs worse than SVM in this case.

3) Performance Comparison

In the third part of our simulations, we compare the proposed algorithm with the baseline from [32], where the optimal τ𝜏\tau is given in Table V. Specifically, the following three categories of comparisons are considered, and their corresponding results are presented in Figs. 3-5.

  • •

    With the same data distribution and dataset, we compare the performance with the baseline for different models.

  • •

    With the same model and dataset, we compare the performance with the baseline for different data distributions.

  • •

    With the same data distribution and model, we compare the performance with the baseline for different datasets.

In Fig. 3 and Fig. 4, both the SVM and the CNN are trained with MNIST, which converge faster than the baseline. For instance, in the SVM with τ=17𝜏17\tau=17 and i.i.d. MNIST as well as τ=10𝜏10\tau=10 and non-i.i.d. MNIST, the loss value converges after 505050 local trainings. However, the number of local trainings in the baseline is around 200200200. On the other hand, the prediction accuracy for both the proposed algorithm and the baseline is close to 0.850.850.85 after convergence. In particular, in the CNN with MNIST, the loss value converges after 202020 local trainings with i.i.d data and τ=20𝜏20\tau=20 while 100100100 with non-i.i.d. data and τ=17𝜏17\tau=17. However, these numbers in the baseline are close to 202020 and 200200200, respectively. Therefore, the convergence speed of our proposed algorithm and the baseline in CNN with MNIST are close to each other. Nevertheless, our proposed algorithm outperforms the baseline in terms of prediction accuracy.

In Fig. 3 and Fig. 4, the results not only reflect the difference between SVM and CNN, but also the difference of data distributions. The convergence speed is faster for the i.i.d. data than that for the non-i.i.d data with the SVM and CNN. For the non-i.i.d. dataset, the proposed algorithm in the SVM and that of the baseline converge after 505050 and 200200200 local trainings, respectively. However, these numbers in the non-i.i.d. data are around 100100100 and 250250250. Furthermore, this phenomenon are also observed in CNN with MNIST. These indicate that the convergence speed for the non-i.i.d. data is slower than that for the i.i.d. data.

In Fig. 4 and Fig. 5, it is seen that both the proposed algorithm and the baseline converge faster with MNIST than CIFAR-10. In the CNN model with MNIST, it converges after 150150150 local trainings. However, with CIFAR-10, it needs 200200200 local trainings for convergence. These indicate that the convergence speed for the easy task with a simple dataset (i.e., less channels and smaller size per sample) is faster than that for the difficult task with a complex dataset.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, we have studied the optimal trade-off between computation and communication in FL with resource restriction. Our goal is to minimize the global loss function while satisfying both the delay and energy consumption requirements. To solve this problem, we have transformed the loss function and derived its closed-form expression in a tractable manner. Through this, we have been able to obtain the optimal number of the local trainings and global aggregations. Furthermore, we have proposed an update algorithm for the implementation of the FL framework. Simulation results have confirmed the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm, i.e., faster convergence and significant performance gain over the conventional ones.

=N​τμ​∑i=1NCN−1i−1​(−1)i−1i2.absent𝑁𝜏𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁1𝑖1superscript1𝑖1superscript𝑖2\displaystyle=\frac{N\tau}{\mu}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{C_{N-1}^{i-1}(-1)^{i-1}}{i^{2}}.

Thus, we know that

𝔼​(max⁡{ti,t​r})≤N​τμ​∑i=1NCN−1i−1​(−1)i−1i2+a​τ.𝔼subscript𝑡𝑖𝑡𝑟𝑁𝜏𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁1𝑖1superscript1𝑖1superscript𝑖2𝑎𝜏\mathbb{E}(\max\{t_{i,tr}\})\leq\frac{N\tau}{\mu}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{C_{N-1}^{i-1}(-1)^{i-1}}{i^{2}}+a\tau. (27)

This completes the proof.

Appendix B Proof of Lemma 2

By using the triangle inequality, we have

|‖∇Fi​(𝐰)‖−‖∇F​(𝐰)‖|≤‖∇Fi​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰)‖.norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰norm∇𝐹𝐰norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰∇𝐹𝐰|\|\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})\|-\|\nabla{F}(\mathbf{w})\||\leq\|\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla{F}(\mathbf{w})\|. (28)

On one hand, by combining (16) and Assumption 1(b), we have

|‖∇Fi​(𝐰)‖−‖∇F​(𝐰)‖|≤δi.norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰norm∇𝐹𝐰subscript𝛿𝑖\big{|}\|\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})\|-\|\nabla{F}(\mathbf{w})\|\big{|}\leq\delta_{{i}}. (29)

On the other hand, by combining (17) and Assumption 2, we have

‖∇Fi​(𝐰)‖≤∇F∗+δi.norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰∇superscript𝐹subscript𝛿𝑖\|\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})\|\leq\nabla{F^{*}}+\delta_{{i}}. (30)

Thus, we can arrive at (10). This completes the proof.

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 2

∥𝐰~i(t−1)−\displaystyle\|\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{{i}}({t-\mathrm{1}})- 𝐰(T)∥≤gi(t−1).\displaystyle\mathbf{w}({T})\|\leq g_{i}(t-\mathrm{1}). (31)

Then, (54) reduces to

x<a2b.𝑥superscript𝑎2𝑏\displaystyle x<\frac{a^{2}}{b}. (56)

By combining these two cases, we have

F​(𝐰​(T))−F​(𝐰∗)≤ϵ2ρ​η​(δ+∇F∗)−τ+ρ​η​∇F∗​T.𝐹𝐰𝑇𝐹superscript𝐰superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜌𝜂𝛿∇superscript𝐹𝜏𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹𝑇\displaystyle\mathit{F}(\mathbf{w}(\mathit{T}))-\mathit{F}(\mathbf{w^{*}})\leq\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{\rho\eta(\delta+\nabla{F^{*}})-\tau+\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}}T}. (57)

This completes the proof.

Appendix E Proof of Theorem 4

The Lagrangian function of (14) is

+λ1​(tc​m​K+(I0​N​μ+a)​K​τ2−tt​o​t)subscript𝜆1subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚𝐾subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎𝐾superscript𝜏2subscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡\displaystyle+\lambda_{1}(t_{cm}K+(I_{0}N\mu+a)K\tau^{2}-t_{tot})

Furthermore, the KKT conditions of (58) are

{∂L∂τ=0,∂L∂K=0,Pc​m​tc​m​K+E​t​r​K​τ−Et​o​t≤0,tc​m​K+(I0​N​μ+a)​K​τ2−tt​o​t≤0,λ1​(tc​m​K+(I0​N​μ+a)​K​τ2−tt​o​t)=0,λ2​(Pc​m​tc​m​K+E​t​r​K​τ−Et​o​t)=0,λ1,λ2≥0.cases𝐿𝜏0otherwise𝐿𝐾0otherwisesubscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚𝐾𝐸𝑡𝑟𝐾𝜏subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡0otherwisesubscript𝑡𝑐𝑚𝐾subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎𝐾superscript𝜏2subscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡0otherwisesubscript𝜆1subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚𝐾subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎𝐾superscript𝜏2subscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡0otherwisesubscript𝜆2subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚𝐾𝐸𝑡𝑟𝐾𝜏subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡0otherwisesubscript𝜆1subscript𝜆20otherwise\begin{cases}\frac{\partial L}{\partial\tau}=0,\\ \frac{\partial L}{\partial K}=0,\\ P_{cm}t_{cm}K+E{tr}K\tau-E_{tot}\leq 0,\\ t_{cm}K+(I_{0}N\mu+a)K\tau^{2}-t_{tot}\leq 0,\\ \lambda_{1}(t_{cm}K+(I_{0}N\mu+a)K\tau^{2}-t_{tot})=0,\\ \lambda_{2}(P_{cm}t_{cm}K+E{tr}K\tau-E_{tot})=0,\\ \lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}\geq 0.\\ \end{cases} (59)

By taking the derivative of (58) with respect to τ𝜏\tau and K𝐾K respectively, and setting them to be equal to zero, we have

{∂L∂τ=1−ρ​η​∇F∗​K+2​λ1​(I0​N​μ+a)​K​τ+λ2​Et​r​K=0,∂L∂K=−ρ​η​∇F∗​τ+λ1​tc​m+λ1​(I0​N​μ+a)​τ2+λ2​Pc​m​tc​m+λ2​Et​r​τ=0.cases𝐿𝜏1𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹𝐾2subscript𝜆1subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎𝐾𝜏subscript𝜆2subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟𝐾0otherwise𝐿𝐾𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹𝜏subscript𝜆1subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚subscript𝜆1subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎superscript𝜏2subscript𝜆2subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚otherwisesubscript𝜆2subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟𝜏0otherwise\begin{cases}\frac{\partial L}{\partial\tau}=1-\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}}K+2\lambda_{\textrm{1}}(I_{0}N\mu+a)K\tau+\lambda_{\textrm{2}}E_{tr}K=\textrm{0},\\ \frac{\partial L}{\partial K}=-\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}}\tau+\lambda_{\textrm{1}}t_{cm}+\lambda_{\textrm{1}}(I_{0}N\mu+a)\tau^{2}+\lambda_{\textrm{2}}P_{cm}t_{cm}\\ \quad\quad\quad+\lambda_{\textrm{2}}E_{tr}\tau=0.\\ \end{cases}

Therefore

{λ1​(I0​N​μ+a)​(τ∗)2−(λ2​Et​r−ρ​η​∇F∗)​τ∗+λ1​tc​m+λ2​Pc​m​tc​m=0,K∗=1ρ​η​∇F∗−2​λ1​(I0​N​μ+a)​τ−λ2​Et​r.casessubscript𝜆1subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎superscriptsuperscript𝜏2subscript𝜆2subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹superscript𝜏otherwisesubscript𝜆1subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚subscript𝜆2subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚0otherwisesuperscript𝐾1𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹2subscript𝜆1subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎𝜏subscript𝜆2subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟otherwise\begin{cases}\lambda_{\textrm{1}}(I_{0}N\mu+a)(\tau^{*})^{2}-(\lambda_{\textrm{2}}E_{tr}-\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}})\tau^{*}\\ \quad\quad\quad+\lambda_{\textrm{1}}t_{cm}+\lambda_{\textrm{2}}P_{cm}t_{cm}=0,\\ K^{*}=\frac{1}{\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}}-2\lambda_{\textrm{1}}(I_{0}N\mu+a)\tau-\lambda_{\textrm{2}}E_{tr}}.\\ \end{cases} (60)

{Pc​m​tc​m​K+E​t​r​K​τ−Et​o​t=0,tc​m​K+(I0​N​μ+a)​K​τ2−tt​o​t=0.casessubscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚𝐾𝐸𝑡𝑟𝐾𝜏subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡0otherwisesubscript𝑡𝑐𝑚𝐾subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎𝐾superscript𝜏2subscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡0otherwise\begin{cases}P_{cm}t_{cm}K+E{tr}K\tau-E_{tot}=0,\\ t_{cm}K+(I_{0}N\mu+a)K\tau^{2}-t_{tot}=0.\\ \end{cases} (61)

where I1=Et​r2​tt​o​t2−4​(I0​N​μ+a)​Et​o​t​(tc​m​Et​o​t−Pc​m​tc​m​tt​o​t)subscript𝐼1subscriptsuperscript𝐸2𝑡𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝑡2𝑡𝑜𝑡4subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡I_{1}=E^{2}_{tr}t^{2}_{tot}-4(I_{0}N\mu+a)E_{tot}(t_{cm}E_{tot}-P_{cm}t_{cm}t_{tot}), and K∗=Et​o​tPc​m​tc​m+Et​r​τ∗superscript𝐾subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟superscript𝜏K^{*}=\frac{E_{tot}}{P_{cm}t_{cm}+E_{tr}\tau^{*}}.

{τ1∗=Et​r​tt​o​t−I12​(I0​N​μ+a)​Et​o​t,K1∗=2​(I0​N​μ+a)​Et​o​t22​(I0​N​μ+a)​Pc​m​tc​m​Et​o​t+Et​r2​tt​o​t−Et​r​I1.casessuperscriptsubscript𝜏1subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟subscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝐼12subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡otherwisesuperscriptsubscript𝐾12subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝐸2𝑡𝑜𝑡2subscript𝐼0𝑁𝜇𝑎subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐸2𝑡𝑟subscript𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟subscript𝐼1otherwise\begin{cases}\tau_{1}^{*}=\frac{E_{tr}t_{tot}-\sqrt{I_{1}}}{2(I_{0}N\mu+a)E_{tot}},\\ K_{1}^{*}=\frac{2(I_{0}N\mu+a)E^{2}_{tot}}{2(I_{0}N\mu+a)P_{cm}t_{cm}E_{tot}+E^{2}_{tr}t_{tot}-E_{tr}\sqrt{I_{1}}}.\end{cases} (64)

Pc​m​tc​m​K+Et​r​K​τ=Et​o​tsubscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚𝐾subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟𝐾𝜏subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡P_{cm}t_{cm}K+E_{tr}K\tau=E_{tot} (66)

Then by substituting λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2} into (67), we get

{τ2∗=1Et​r​(ρ​η​∇F∗​Pc​m​tc​m​Et​o​t−Pc​m​tc​m),K2∗=Et​o​tρ​η​∇F∗​Pc​m​tc​m.casessuperscriptsubscript𝜏21subscript𝐸𝑡𝑟𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚otherwisesuperscriptsubscript𝐾2subscript𝐸𝑡𝑜𝑡𝜌𝜂∇superscript𝐹subscript𝑃𝑐𝑚subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚otherwise\begin{cases}\tau_{2}^{*}=\frac{1}{E_{tr}}(\sqrt{\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}}P_{cm}t_{cm}E_{tot}}-P_{cm}t_{cm}),\\ K_{2}^{*}=\sqrt{\frac{E_{tot}}{\rho\eta\nabla{F^{*}}P_{cm}t_{cm}}}.\end{cases} (68)

Finally, because Ti∗=Ki∗​τi∗,i=1,2formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖𝑖12T_{i}^{*}=K_{i}^{*}\tau_{i}^{*},i=1,2, to make sure the optimal τ𝜏\tau and K𝐾K are realistic, which should satisfy the following constraints

{τ1∗,K1∗≥1,τ2∗,K2∗≥1.casessubscriptsuperscript𝜏1subscriptsuperscript𝐾11otherwisesubscriptsuperscript𝜏2subscriptsuperscript𝐾21otherwise\begin{cases}\tau^{*}_{1},K^{*}_{1}\geq 1,\\ \tau^{*}_{2},K^{*}_{2}\geq 1.\end{cases} (72)

After some manipulations, we can arrive at (19). This completes the proof.
